actions.text: Referred to Senate Committee on the Judiciary.
Reported to Senate from the Committee on the Judiciary with amendment, S. Rept. 93-500.
Referred to House Committee on the Judiciary.
Reported to House from the Committee on the Judiciary, H. Rept. 93-1569.

official_title: To improve judicial machinery by amending title 28, United States Code, with respect to judicial review of decisions of the Interstate Commerce Commission, and for other purposes.

summary.text: (LATEST SUMMARY) Provides that the U.S. district courts shall have jurisdiction of any civil action to enforce, enjoin, or suspend, in whole or in part, any order of the Interstate Commerce Commission for the payment of money or the collection of fines, penalties, and forfeitures. Transfers judicial review of other Commission actions to the circuit courts. States that a civil action shall be brought only in the judicial district in which any of the parties bringing the action resides or has its principal office. Provides that the court of appeals shall have exclusive jurisdiction to review final orders of the Commission. States that the Attorney General shall represent the Government in any such action. Provides that the courts of appeals shall have jurisdiction over any proceeding to enjoin or suspend, in whole or in part, a rule, regulation, or order of the Commission and specifies that such proceedings shall be brought in the manner prescribed by the Hobbs Act (28 U.S.C. 2341-2351).

titles.title: To improve judicial machinery by amending title 28, United States Code, with respect to judicial review of decisions of the Interstate Commerce Commission, and for other purposes.
